ygData.subject: Re: [cantera] Installation
ygData.msgSnippet: Sarah, On a unix system, the sequence ./configure make make install should work if you have write access to /usr/local.  If not, give the prefix option to

Sarah,

On a unix system, the sequence

./configure
make
make install

should work if you have write access to /usr/local.  If not, give the  
'prefix' option to 'configure':

./configure --prefix==<install_dir>,

where <install_dir> is the directory where you want Cantera installed.

If configure is selecting the wrong compiler, edit it before running  
it.  Maybe try to install the binary PC version if you have a PC  
available.
Or if you send me directly (not through the users group) the error  
messages you are gettiing, I can tell you what is wrong.

Dave Goodwin



On Thursday, June 5, 2003, at 01:31 PM, Sarah J. Warthesen wrote:

> Hi Dr. Goodwin,
>
> I am a graduate student at the University of Minnesota, working with  
> Dr.
> Girshick, and we are interested in using Cantera to work with our  
> complex
> silane plasma chemistry mechanism.  I have attempted to install  
> version 1.4
> for Unix, and so far I have not gotten through the "make install"  
> step.  I
> have spent some time following the paths of compilation, and I believe  
> I'm
> making progress, but I thought you might have a simple suggestion of  
> how to
> get Cantera up and running.  The problem seems to be that the necessary
> files are not present in the correct directories, or the correct  
> compiler is
> not being used - I'm not entirely sure, but trying to compile each  
> small
> file individually does not seem efficient.  I appreciate any advice  
> you can
> give, but I will keep working on it as is.  Also, I just wanted to let  
> you
> know that we are very excited to work with Cantera.
>
> Thanks,
>
> Sarah Warthesen
>
>
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: dggoodwin [mailto:dgoodwin@...]
> Sent: Friday, February 15, 2002 11:00 AM
> To: cantera@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [cantera] progress report
>
>
>
> Sometimes I wonder what I've gotten myself into with Cantera... it
> turns out (big surprise) that developing a large software project is
> A Big Job. Particularly when one has a day job...
>
> Anyway, significant progress is being made, although it may not seem
> like it (to anyone but me). In particular, the first really-useful
> Cantera application is almost ready - a one dimensional reacting-flow
> application, that can be used to simulate:
>
> - 1D laminar flames
> - counterflow flames
> - stagnation-point flows with surface chemistry (CVD, catalysis, etc.)
>
> I expect it will be ready to ship in a couple of weeks... stay tuned.
>
>
>
